Comparing performance of dplyr vs. base

Mauro Lepore

2017-08-29

Measuring performance

library(forestr)
library(bci)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

x <- bci12full7

system.time({
  with_dplyr <- count_status(x = x, .status = "A", sp)
  with_dplyr <- arrange(with_dplyr, sp)
})
#>    user  system elapsed 
#>    1.46    0.03    1.53

system.time({
  # There may be a faster and more elegant way to do this in base
  .split <- split(x, x$sp)
  applied_1 <- lapply(.split, ctfs::abundance)
  applied_2 <- lapply(applied_1, "[[", "abund")
  
  sp <- names(applied_2)
  n <- lapply(applied_2, "[[", "all")
  n <- unlist(n)
  with_base <- data.frame(sp, n, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
  with_base <- with_base[order(with_base$sp), ]
})
#>    user  system elapsed 
#>    1.70    0.17    1.91

head(with_dplyr)
#> # A tibble: 6 x 2
#>       sp     n
#>    <chr> <dbl>
#> 1 acacme    49
#> 2 acaldi  1146
#> 3 acalma    53
#> 4 ade1tr   146
#> 5 aegipa    40
#> 6 alchco   317

head(with_base)
#>            sp    n
#> acacme acacme   49
#> acaldi acaldi 1146
#> acalma acalma   53
#> ade1tr ade1tr  146
#> aegipa aegipa   40
#> alchco alchco  317

all.equal(with_dplyr, with_base)
#> [1] TRUE
